comments.commentBody: My least favorite tort attorney combined with my least favorite failed CEO. Suddenly every other choice looks great.
The election cycle is too long. We must figure out some way to shorten it.
Every once in a while politics gives us a theater of the absurd that trumps any literary version. This is that while, but there is more than one once in it. (Sigh.)

Sanders and Trump both encouraged by media for money at risk to USA wellbeing.  Think about other authoritarian leaders who rid media to take power; this incidence media elevated and or prolonged rise.So now Trumps very status gives the lowest of us to attack the least of us.
Be sure to counter with "What the ...." questions about Europe 's self -inflicted migrant quagmire.
You can respond by asking, depending on which country you're in, about their own homegrown fascist party.

True, but most of those countries have a history of a large number of political parties that have a chance of having at least a few representatives in the government, some definitely on the fringes. We have two.
In my travels, for what it's worth, a lot of people who I meet in Europe have long looked to us as an example of relative stability and the questions are not given with a negative sense to them.
Well, pretty soon I'm off to Europe for a while where I can be asked in many various ways the question, "What the ....?". To which I don't have a decent answer.

I understand under privileged but how can one be over-privileged?
Should I understand that to mean that Sanders thinks some people are not entitled to what they've earned?

Heading into California with Carly Fiorina at his side should be interesting. It could only be more surreal if they decide to resurrect some form of the demon sheep ad; at least hire the guy responsible. What a hoot.

If you think young voters have money for Sanders, you must have been born like Trump was. No, most donations are in small amounts and for one, this donor is no longer young. Bernie has only $17 millions cash left. Unlike Clinton who owed millions of campaign debt after losing to Obama, Bernie spends responsibly and owes 0 debt. Below are some Sanders donation descriptive statistics.
https://www.opensecrets.org/pres16/candidate.php?id=N00000528
https://www.opensecrets.org/pres16/donordemcid.php?cycle=2016&id=N00...

I'm continuing my support and looking forward to voting for Sanders in the CA primary; but I agree with you on the need to, well, vary his emphases. But I think you'll find there is info on the www.berniesanders.com website and in the Rolling Stone interview that gives more info than he was able or allowed to reveal during the debates.
I do believe his remarks about Palestine could dramatically alter the US's relationship with alienated Muslims and also Christian Arabs in the Middle East.

We all hope that he continues to do the very good and important work that he does in the US Senate and maybe continues to publicize his approach to the issues a little more widely than he did in the past.

Unfortunately for Sanders, his Robin Hood crusade seems to lose steam among his older constituents; he's been getting much more support from the younger voters. I think he should turn down the crusade just a notch and talk about other pressing issues- everyone now knows he's firmly (and loudly) on the side of the underprivileged, and wants the over-privileged to pay a fairer share. I’d like to get a better idea how he’d handle some of the other issues, such as terrorism, keeping a handle on nuclear proliferation, and global warming. He has shown himself to be very hard worker and a pragmatic guy who really thinks things through, and I’d like to hear what he’s thought about regarding these other issues. I’m wondering if that’s what other older people are waiting to hear, as well.

When LBJ
s anti-poverty programs cranked up we had 14.3 % of the population living below the government determined poverty line.
Today, $23 Trillion later we have 14.3% living under the same figure.
Why would anyone hold to the idea that taking the hard earned assets of the Middle Class is going to improve on that?
With a rapidly disappearing Middle Class the US is starting to resemble a banana republic with a wealthy oligarchy on top, the poor on the bottom and nothing in the middle.
Yes, we'd like to see everyone better off but doing it as we did. Working our way out of poverty to at least Middle Class. Most of the poor are where they are due to a low moral standard. Unless that changes we're just throwing money away and enabling a continuance in poverty only with better TVs and consumerist junk.

Where I come from, Sanders is a mainstream politician. We don't believe in blaming the poor for poverty or the sick for disease.
That you speak of your countrymen with such derision is disgusting. The fact that those who have it won't, speaks ill of your society and by reflection, you.

As if I could care.
And we can blame them for the things they did to get where they are and the things they do to stay there. It's a fact of life, if you want to be poor have children as a teenager, drop out of school, do drugs.

Those crying over Santa Sanders Socialism would be last in line to share their assets, or deny its investment growth stymying WallStreet's performance.  He has big following from those who don't have and can't, but not from those who do have it and won't do.
Any time someone says there is only one answer, it is usually the wrong answer.
It will probably be too late when media and other  critics realize Clinton is only person between USA and Italy 1920s.
In all fairness, though, even the Cruz campaign is referring to the ticket as "Cruz/Carly."

You must be in a privileged position to make light of such a serious situation for the workers at Verizon.

Also, comparing campaign work to industry work is ridiculous -- everyone knows that they are doing short-term work when they sign up for a campaign... Go ask the people in Clinton's campaign, if you have any doubts.
Campaign worker jobs are temporary and people know this when they sign up.  Bernie was smart to realign funds to stay in the running to this point.
What a stupid comparison!

What? Bernie is laying off 700 campaign workers? Does this mean Verizon management can now start protesting in front of his headquarters over how he is treating redundant employees?

Bernie should put his money where is mouth is and begin a retraining program immediately for those 700 to prove he can maintain full employment where capitalists can't.
Its funny because it's true.  I worked for Compaq in 2001 during the HP merger.  Morale deteriorated very fast.
It's not that bad-- he's being careful with all our $27 contributions, and also those paid-staffers know it's a temporary job.  Maybe they'll be back in business for November.....!

4/27
I am so sorry. Sorry that Bernie had to scale back and sorry we will have to see more of Ted and Carly.
Prayer would be the correct strategy, since there is no known person who could possibly win and who yet possesses the qualifications you seek.

What you say is not true Mark.

All you need have done would have been to have ever gone to her website to know that most of what you say is clearly false.

Most of the rest of your post has never been established as fact, but simply a
'talking point' invented by Bernie to try to win over voters.

As far as Syria and Libya and Iraq go, you might want to look to Bernie's voting history on this to see that his position (except in one case) was not actually different than Hillary's.

However, he chose to cherry pick, and use in 20/20 hindsight, the 'one time' he voted against intervention as proof that his judgement was somehow different than hers, and that of the majority, and ignores the many other times he voted for it.

Bernie has been brutally dishonest in molding a negative image of his opponent. I feel you are simply uniformed. Please go to the fact check sites, PolitiFact and FactCheck and to Hillary's website. Particularly good its the analysis of the sixth debate and "Fossil Fuel Money Revisited"

http://www.factcheck.org/2016/04/clintons-fossil-fuel-money-revisited/

Senator Sanders has but a few years on me.....we are of the same generation............we share the same values............gathered and tested at a time of national upheaval.

It saddens me to know that the Democratic Party has had to move so far to the right in response to the suicide-right-winged Republicans that to strive for the values of Senator Sanders has become an over-reach. Such an overreach is it that to try for it all at once is too risky. Best elect Clinton to go for it step by step.

Even so, Senator Sanders has redirected us to the moral high ground. Strange how lonely it is up here.

Vote accordingly in November.
This kind of stubborn purity is what could give Trump a victory. It certainly put Bush in power. That really helped the world.

Trump is neoconservatives' biggest nightmare. He represents continuation of non-interventionalist Obama policies. Hillary is their girl, but Sanders voters will spoil the coronation party by voting for Trump.
The NYT thinks that Obama is serious, Bernie's "style" is merely benignly amusing and not surprisingly that Trump is dangerous. Is this new?

The front page article says that the Hillary response to Trump's foreign policy speech was laid out by a Bush era neocon who now advises her:

"R. Nicholas Burns, a former senior State Department official under Mr. Bush who now advises Mrs. Clinton, said, “He’s casting these thunderbolts and threats at our allies, and yet there was almost a kid-glove treatment of Russia and China.”"

So there you have it. Hillary has the Bush people to do new Hillary Wars, continuations of the Bush Wars.

The article quotes a whole list of the supporters of Bush's disasters attacking Trump for suggesting something different, while Hillary promises more of the same failed foreign policy. Naturally, since that is what she wanted and pushed for as Sec of State, restrained only by Obama.

Trump promised to change our approach. Hillary's response is that it won't change.

It should be clear that more of the same is wrong.

Never forget that the NYT supported the Iraq War, strongly, until it was far past too late. They are doing it again in this Editorial.

Criminalizing texting in the country with the largest prison population in the world ain't the answer.

Are we not smart enough to come up with a reasonable and implementable solution?
You are just saying...what exactly?  That two wrongs make a right?
Police type or text while driving as they do random checks of license plates. I am just saying and I am pro police.

This is great news. Colorado has a stretch of I-25 that is two lanes in each direction and 75 mph. That means trucks in the left lane are going 55 or 60 while everyone else, including those wishing to go 90 are in the right lane. Put texting into this mix, plus aggressive driving, and you have a stretch of freeway that routinely has accidents. I drive it up and down twice a week and there are accidents regularly. Drivers can call *277 to report erratic or aggressive driving, but that, of course, means getting on your phone in the midst of it all.

What ever happened to patience? To the sweet beauty of a few minutes of alone time, of quiet? Is this something we will have to begin to teach children in school?

never drink and drive.
never text and drive.
be aware of prescription and other drugs.
always wear your seat belt.be

with that in mind, please also know that:

"While many factors likely contributed to the fatality increase, a stronger economy and lower unemployment rates are likely at the core of the trend. Average gas prices were 28% lower in 2015 than in 2014 and are projected to continue dropping this year, making driving more affordable for many Americans. The U.S. Department of Transportation estimates a 3.5% increase in the number of miles driven in 2015 compared to 2014."

Studies have shown that talking on the phone while driving still puts the driver at more risk, comparable to impaired driving--DUI. This is because the driver is focused on the person on the phone who can't see or be aware of a driving situation developing like a passenger can, so the driver can lose precious seconds trying to disengage from a phone conversation, as well as lose focus on driving altogether. Better to leave talking on the phone for when you're not driving or for emergencies only.

People with a texting problem will find an easy solution -- a dummy phone which is handed over to the police very easily while the driver's regular phone is hidden away. Problem solved for the person with a texting and driving compulsion.

Far less outrageous than the idiot on his phone who plows into another car and kills 5 people.

Smartphones are just portable computers. When you use a phone and the internet what level of privacy do you have, expect, or need? These devices are have now been distributed to everybody. People are addicted to them and can't put them down. The car manufacturers supply features that encourage their use while driving. The automobile has simply become a moving living room and people truly forget that not only are they going 60, 70, and 8o mph, but that they have to actually watch where they are going, too. The roads have become a house of horrors and the possible invasion of the privacy I may have over my phone contacts and usage is the last thing I am worried about. I am far more concerned with my car being invaded by another vehicle.
